image.altText: A damaged overhead compartment on flight SQ321

props.synopsis: As the details of the devastating injuries sustained onboard flight SQ321 emerge, attention is turning to what happens to these passengers and crew now and what can be done to make all the hours spent in an aircraft cabin safer.

title.children: Turbulence caused 'life-changing' injuries for dozens of passengers. Now, flying could change

image.altText: A South Koran man in a room looking despondent.

props.synopsis: Almost a quarter of a million South Koreans have withdrawn from the outside world. Meet two of them.

title.children: Wren lived in his walk-in-wardrobe for three months — he is one of thousands of South Korean 'shut-ins'

image.altText: Jim Chalmers holds a copy of the 2024 Budget papers as he arrives at Parliament House

props.synopsis: In the past 10-15 years, there has been bipartisan support for a range of decisions that profoundly increase the cost of government. Yet the hysterical alarm at increases in the size of government spending fail to acknowledge this.

title.children: Hysterical alarm at increases in government spending fails to acknowledge the elephant in the room

image.altText: Four Israeli tanks drive in a line, with small Israeli flags flying from them.

props.synopsis: The International Court of Justice orders Israel to halt its military offensive in southern Gaza in a landmark ruling which is unlikely to have any impact on the ground.

title.children: UN's top court orders Israel to halt Rafah offensive in landmark ruling

image.altText: A woman crouches outdoors, and touches something in a small box with her hands, while looking away from the camera

props.synopsis: Rulings in the UN's top court are considered binding, but enforcing them is another story. Just minutes after the ICJ ordered Israel to stop its assault on Rafah, the IDF bombed the city again.

title.children: Why ICJ decision is unlikely to stop invasion in Gaza

image.altText: Machinery and a solitary walker on an Adelaide beach.

props.synopsis: Dredging will be trialled along Adelaide's northern beaches as part of the state government's latest attempt to fix sand drift and erosion.  Sand will be taken from between North Haven and Taperoo then relocated south where erosion is more acute.

title.children: Dredging and barging sand along Adelaide's disappearing coastline to be trialled

image.altText: A woman in a dark blue shirt holds a baby who is clothed, in her arms.

props.synopsis: A lack of resources and workforce shortages in birthing services at regional SA hospitals have forced mothers needing urgent or specialised care to travel as far as Adelaide.

title.children: Regional SA mums forced to make 'stressful' 650km trip to give birth

image.altText: RBA reno 1

props.synopsis: Renovating the Reserve Bank's headquarters is increasingly looking like a disastrous episode of home building show Grand Designs. The key difference? The budget for the horror reno is now north of $1 billion.

title.children: The Block and Grand Designs have nothing on the RBA's billion-dollar renovation horror show

image.altText: a crowd of people walking on a dirty road, two people carry a stretcher made out of tree branches.

props.synopsis: More than 100 people are believed to have been killed in a landslide that buried a village in a remote, mountainous part of Papua New Guinea, with helicopters the only way of accessing the region.

title.children: Landslides hampering rescue efforts in remote PNG village, where more than 100 are believed dead

image.altText: A generic image of compounded semaglutide in a small bottle, with a pharmacy label and red liquid, next to a syringe.

props.synopsis: One bad apple spoils the barrel — that seems to be the current predicament for Australia's compounding pharmacists.

title.children: Pharma's mess of its own making — greed, secrecy and weight-loss drugs

image.altText: An illustration of two women from behind, sitting before a magistrate. One has their arm around the other.

props.synopsis: A small room within a Sydney courthouse is packed full of women who have experienced domestic violence and the workers trained to help them make sense of legal process. Inside it, the true scale of the crisis is laid bare.

title.children: 'You try not to think about what they're going home to': A day on the frontline of Australia's domestic violence crisis

image.altText: A man wearing a black polo shirt and white apron stands behind a barbecue cooking a steak.

props.synopsis: The heat has been put on Network Ten in a Senate inquiry into greenwashing and executives refused to put a number on a controversial gas sponsorship deal for its successful MasterChef show.

title.children: 'Gas lobby forced-fed down our throat': MasterChef grilled in greenwashing Senate inquiry

image.altText: Man on phone, in warm-coloured room, with lamp on in background

props.synopsis: Degrading behaviour towards women is common in 'mainstream' pornography, according to Australia's eSafety commissioner. What sort of impact is this having on teenagers and adults?

title.children: 'Men have to be the brutalisers': What are the impacts of misogynistic porn?

image.altText: duttonalbanesemigration

props.synopsis: Even as the migration debate threatens to get bitter and ugly, Australia's politicians agree more than they disagree. Where will the political debate lead us on the policy front?

title.children: The migration debate is heating up, but will the war of words lead to action?

image.altText: Morgan Spurlock smiling

props.synopsis: Oscar-nominated documentary filmmaker Morgan Spurlock, who made food and American diets his life's work by famously eating only at McDonald's for a month to illustrate the dangers of a fast-food diet, dies from complications related to cancer.

title.children: Super Size Me filmmaker Morgan Spurlock dies aged 53

image.altText: Nutbush world record at Big Red Bash

props.synopsis: A study by universities in SA and WA has sought to shed light on the origin of the popular Australian dance routine to American singer Tina Turner's 1973 song Nutbush City Limits, and has determined it was invented by the NSW education department.

title.children: The Nutbush dance is an Australian icon — but it owes its origins to a teachers' meeting

image.altText: A female footy player hugs another player on field

props.synopsis: For 70 First Nations football fans, it's the ultimate reward for effort — a chance to meet their heroes and do a lap of the Melbourne Cricket Ground in front of thousands of attendees.

title.children: Budding Aboriginal talents head to Dreamtime match in 'cup-filling' experience

image.altText: woman sitting in her van with possessions in the back

props.synopsis: Homeless since returning to Australia seven months ago, Dr Selene Routley is a physicist and space scientist who makes a small income writing articles for science magazines. She currently sleeps in a van packed to the brim with her possessions.

title.children: Homeless physicist 'sick of smelling of my own BO' living in a van in a region with impossible rent

image.altText: A woman, smiling, with some cows.

props.synopsis: When urban Mancunian Sarah Moore and her wife Emily decided to give dairy farming a go in South Australia they found a reason to get up in the morning and doing a good day's work was a fine reason to stay.

title.children: A backpacker loved working on a dairy farm so much she became the manager

image.altText: A dark blue sign advertising a $150 million lottery prize is mounted on a shiny red wall.

props.synopsis: An Adelaide man has come forward to claim Thursday's $150 million Powerball jackpot, becoming Australia's biggest lottery winner in the process.

title.children: 'I want to buy a house and travel the world': Adelaide man claims $150 million Powerball jackpot after sleepless night

image.altText: Ram Khanal smiles and gives a thumbs up. He's standing in front of mountains, with a friend on each side.

props.synopsis: Ram Khanal's recent trip to Mount Everest base camp was the realisation of a long-held dream. But it was also a homecoming of sorts.

title.children: I spent my first 16 years in a Nepalese refugee camp. This year, I returned to trek Mount Everest

image.altText: Emergency services and traffic at a suburban street.

props.synopsis: Two people are dead and a third is being rushed to hospital following a shooting in Perth's western suburbs.

title.children: Two people dead, another rushed to hospital after shooting in Perth

image.altText: Harry Grant looks into the distance

props.synopsis: Melbourne coach Craig Bellamy wants the NRL to put an end to five-day turnarounds with heavy travel, unhappy with his side's schedule through May.

title.children: Bellamy points finger at arduous schedule for lengthy Storm injury list

image.altText: A group of people walk around on some rocks around a mountain.

props.synopsis: Australia's Foreign Minister Penny Wong says Australia is ready to assist in recovery efforts after a huge landslide struck the remote Kaokalam Village in Papua New Guinea, leaving more than 100 people estimated dead.

title.children: 'The loss of life and damage is devastating': Australia ready to assist after landslide strikes PNG village

image.altText: A group of young men walk over piles of rocks and debris, with a green forest in the background.

props.synopsis: In addition to its hilly terrain, seismic activity and tropical climate, Papua New Guinea's population is spread across the country in a way that makes it particularly vulnerable to landslide fatalities.

title.children: Why does Papua New Guinea experience so many fatal landslides — and what can be done to help?

image.altText: Rear view of unidentified computer hacker looking at computer screen.

props.synopsis: The health company at the centre of a cyber attack asks the federal government for a bailout, as personal information about some Australians is posted for sale online.

title.children: MediSecure asks for government bailout after cyberhack, data advertised on dark web

image.altText: Charred pages of books amid rubble

props.synopsis: A "bright yellow spark" and then an explosion — residents of Kharkiv, just kilometres from the Russian border, are bracing for further onslaughts.

title.children: In the aftermath of Russia's latest attack on Kharkiv, thousands of burned books blanket the ground

image.altText: A stern looking man in a white polo shirt.

props.synopsis: Disgraced AFL player Barry Cable is charged with sexually abusing a young girl in the 1960s.

title.children: Disgraced AFL player Barry Cable charged with sexual abuse of young girl

image.altText: A photo of colourful lottery balls stacked on top one another with a hand grabbing the top green ball

props.synopsis: No matter whether you've won the jackpot or only $10, two things happen to unclaimed winnings from the lotto: they go back to the government or wait for you to collect.

title.children: 19 lotto prizes worth up to $15 million remain unclaimed. Here's what happens to them

image.altText: A woman and three men in a kitchen. The men are chopping vegetables and singing.

props.synopsis: They've travelled far from home to help their families in Fiji, but this group of PALM workers spends their Saturdays off cooking in Brisbane for Australians struggling with the cost of living.

title.children: With 'simple cooking' and Fijian music, these PALM workers are helping Australians struggling with cost of living

image.altText: The Dockers' Alex Pearce points to the sky after kicking a late goal against the Magpies.

props.synopsis: Walyalup/Fremantle captain Alex Pearce reveals he was thinking of his former Dockers teammate Cam McCarthy, who died earlier this month, as he took his shot on goal that helped the hosts salvage a draw with Collingwood in Perth.

title.children: 'Cam would kick this': Pearce pays tribute to former teammate as Dockers snatch dramatic draw with Magpies

image.altText: A group of protesters on a sidewalk waving flags. A policeman stands near them.

props.synopsis: Seven people have now died since riots broke out over proposed electoral changes in the French territory.

title.children: A day after the French president called for calm, a protester has been killed in New Caledonia

image.altText: Stack of several thousand dollars of Australian $50 notes

props.synopsis: Winning the lottery could be life-changing if you spend the money right. We spoke to four personal finance experts for their hypothetical tips if you were to receive a windfall.

title.children: Four financial advisers reveal what to do if you ever win the lottery or receive a surprise inheritance

image.altText: thumbnail

props.synopsis: Australians love their "big things", according to a history expert, and don't like them being messed with — as one New South Wales council recently discovered.

title.children: Hook, line and stinker — why the 'hideous' revamp of this tiny town's Big Trout left locals fuming
